summary: A documentary-style video capturing the triumph and challenges faced by participants in the 2024 Barkley Marathons, highlighting the major achievement of Jasmin Paris.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a person sitting on a couch, wearing a dark bathrobe, in a room adorned with medals and a shelf of water bottles. A colorful light strip runs along the wall behind them, and an orange banner with the word "ANIFT" is visible. The person appears to be speaking, as indicated by their mouth movements and the text overlay stating, "Yes, I am in my bath robe." The scene transitions to a black-and-white photograph of a man leaning on a railing, wearing a white t-shirt with a graphic and a backpack. The text overlay reads, "The first ever finisher of the Barkley Marathons was a Brit. Mark Williams completed all five loops in 1995." The video then displays a table listing the years, names, times, and notes of various marathon finishers, including Mark Williams, David Horton, Blake Wood, Teddy Keizer, Mike Tilden, Jim Nelson, Brian Robinson, and Andrew Thompson, highlighting their achievements and records. The table provides a historical context of the marathon's progression over the years.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single male speaker excitedly announcing a record-breaking achievement in the Barkley Marathons, celebrating Jasmine Paris as the first woman to complete all five loops. The speaker transitions into a more descriptive tone, detailing the history of the race, founded by Gary Cantrell, also known as Lazarus Lake, evolving from a 50-mile race to the current challenging 100-mile and over course. Then, the speaker notes that only 17 individuals had ever finished the race before today. Simultaneously, there is the sound of a paper being rustled, which fades out towards the end.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man in a dark robe sitting on a couch in a room adorned with medals and a shelf of water bottles, with a sign reading 'NIFT' in the background. The scene transitions to an outdoor setting where a person in a black jacket and shorts stands on a dirt path, surrounded by trees and a fence. The next scene shows a man in a black jacket with 'GORE' written on it, standing in front of a tent decorated with British flags, with a table and various items visible in the background. The video then returns to the man in the dark robe on the couch, followed by a scene of a person in a green shirt and red cap, equipped with trekking poles and a backpack, walking towards a stone structure in a wooded area. The video concludes with the person in the green shirt interacting with a man behind the stone structure, with other people and a child visible in the background.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with one male speaker, excited to give an update on the Barkley Marathon, detailing how runners headed off and mentioning one friend, "Henrik Boorey" from the UK. He describes Henrik's previous accomplishments and notes that he "managed one loop which is absolutely amazing." The tone remains positive, highlighting how "some people start the Barkley, don't even get that far."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man sitting on a couch, wearing a dark robe and a gray shirt, in a room adorned with medals and a shelf filled with water bottles. The background features a colorful light strip and a red banner with the word "ENJOY" (enjoy) written on it. The scene transitions to an outdoor setting where the same man is seen running, dressed in a white tank top, a cap, and a bandana around his neck, holding a water bottle. The video then returns to the indoor setting, showing the man back on the couch, still in his robe and gray shirt, with the same background elements visible. The video alternates between these two scenes, highlighting the man's activities both indoors and outdoors.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing participants in the Barkley race, mentioning Harvey Lewis and his previous world record at Big's Backyard Ultra. The speaker states that Harvey "didn't make it to the end" and "tapped out quite early on".

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man in a dark robe sitting on a couch in a room adorned with medals and a shelf of water bottles, with a colorful light strip behind him. The scene transitions to an outdoor setting where a man in a blue cap and backpack interacts with another man in a white shirt, surrounded by trees. The video then returns to the man in the robe, who continues to speak in the same room. The narrative shifts to an outdoor event where a man in a blue cap and black outfit greets a crowd behind a metal barrier, with flags and a sign reading "DISPLAY PERMIT ON DASH OF EACH VEHICLE" in the background. The video concludes with the man in the robe speaking again, maintaining the same background and setting.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features a single male speaker enthusiastically discussing "Harvey's assist" at a world record. He mentions someone named "Ior Verries," praising them as "the very first person back" at the Barkley Marathons, and implies Ior was essentially "the winner" this year. The speaker then congratulates Henrik and Ior with a tone of admiration, saying "fantasticly well done, amazing finish by Ior." Finally, a distinct "tick" sound can be heard.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of an Indiana license plate reading 'BARKLEY' with the tagline 'The Crossroads of America' beneath it, set against a black and white backdrop. The scene transitions to a man in a dark robe sitting on a couch, surrounded by medals and trophies, with a shelf of water bottles and a neon light strip in the background. The man appears to be speaking, as his mouth moves and his head shifts slightly. The video then shifts to an outdoor setting where two individuals, one in a black cap and blue vest and the other in an orange shirt and black beanie, are seen running on a residential street. The scene returns to the man in the robe, who continues to speak, with the background remaining consistent. The video then shows two men conversing in a wooded area, one wearing a black visor and the other a white cap, both equipped with hydration packs. The video concludes with the man in the robe continuing his speech, maintaining the same background elements throughout.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker talking about two runners and their history in the Barkley Marathon, including one named John Kelly who he interviewed previously. The speaker emphasizes how Kelly completed a third finish, followed by discussing Jared Campbell's goal and how he had a DNF the previous year but ultimately finished, becoming the first person to complete four Barkley Marathons. His tone is enthusiastic and celebratory.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man sitting on a couch, wearing a dark robe and a gray shirt, in a room adorned with medals and trophies on the wall, and a shelf with various items, including a red banner with the word "SWIFT" (Swift). The room is illuminated by a colorful LED light strip. The scene transitions to an outdoor setting where a woman in an orange shirt and black shorts is running uphill on a forest trail, using trekking poles. The video then returns to the man on the couch, who appears to be speaking, with the same background and lighting. The scene shifts to an outdoor event where several people are gathered around a table, engaging in conversation and activities. The video concludes with a table displaying a list of names, genders, and times, indicating a race or event results. The atmosphere throughout the video is casual and focused on outdoor activities and achievements.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker recapping some significant stories, focusing on "Jasmine Paris and Damien Hall", both "huge ultra running stars". He speaks in an enthusiastic tone, giving details about their performances in a specific race. The background music is upbeat and positive, with notable electronic elements, contributing to the overall motivational atmosphere. The speaker talks about how "weather was kind" for race. The audio transitions to a summary stating "seven runners were still in the game" at one point, including Damien Hall and Jasmine Paris.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man sitting on a couch, wearing a dark robe and a gray shirt, in a room decorated with medals and a shelf of water bottles. The background features a colorful LED light strip and a sign with the word "SNIFT" in orange. The scene transitions to a black-and-white image of a woman running in a forest, wearing a backpack and a long-sleeved shirt. The video then returns to the man on the couch, who appears to be speaking. The next scene shows a woman sitting on a chair behind a metal barrier, surrounded by people and photographers, with a blue flag featuring a crest in the background. The video continues with the man on the couch, still speaking, and then transitions to another black-and-white image of a woman running in a forest, this time with a backpack and trekking poles. The video concludes with the man on the couch, continuing his speech.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a male speaker describing the Barkley race, noting that the first 46 hours were "relatively uneventful." He speaks in an informative tone, mentioning the comfortable weather and confident runners, but emphasizes the challenge of the last loop. He highlights how runners help each other, "helping each other find the books" and maintain morale. The clip contains no music or background noise.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man in a dark robe sitting on a couch, surrounded by various medals and trophies on the wall behind him, indicating a history of achievements. The room is warmly lit, with a colorful LED strip light adding a modern touch. The scene transitions to an outdoor setting where a runner, dressed in an orange shirt and black shorts, navigates through a dense forest, using trekking poles to aid his movement. The forest is filled with dry, brown vegetation, suggesting a late autumn or early winter season. The video then returns to the man in the robe, who appears to be speaking, possibly sharing insights or stories related to the runner's journey. The narrative continues with a black-and-white shot of another runner, this time wearing a backpack and trekking poles, ascending a steep, wooded hill, emphasizing the physical challenge of the trail. The video then shifts to a color scene of a different runner, dressed in a blue jacket and black shorts, running on a paved path in a wooded area, with spectators in the background, highlighting the communal aspect of the event. The video concludes with the man in the robe, now with a colorful LED strip light behind him, continuing his dialogue, possibly reflecting on the experiences of the runners.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single male speaker discussing the challenges runners face in a race, specifically "going in opposite directions" and "navigating in the dark." The speaker emphasizes the runners potentially being "on their own" for the first time. His tone is informative and descriptive. A brief musical interlude follows with a somber and calm tone. The male speaker then resumes, noting that "as we got closer to 60 hours," the first of the runners "made it back."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man in a blue cap and blue vest running along a road, passing by a white truck with a colorful design and a group of people behind a metal barrier. The man continues running, with a sign reading "BIG CREEK TRAILHEAD" visible in the background. He is wearing black shorts, white knee-high socks, and black running shoes with yellow accents. The scene transitions to the man running further down the road, with a stone wall and more spectators visible. The man then slows down and walks, with another person in a black cap and black outfit taking photos of him. The video then shifts to an indoor setting, where a man in a dark robe is sitting on a white couch, speaking. The background features a wall with medals, a shelf with water bottles, and a sign that reads "SNIFT" (a brand of water bottles). The man appears to be in a relaxed and comfortable environment, possibly discussing his running experience.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker congratulating a person named "Eor" from Canada and Ukraine for making it back to the Yellow Gate in a certain time. He sounds celebratory and excited. There is then a pause before he continues speaking, noting that they had to wait a few minutes longer before the second runner came back.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a group of people gathered around a stone structure in a snowy outdoor setting, where one person in a yellow and black shirt is handing a piece of paper to another individual wearing a brown coat and a red hat with white text. Nearby, a person in an orange shirt and red headband is holding onto a yellow railing. The scene transitions to a close-up of a person in a yellow and black shirt drinking water from a tree, with water dripping down their face. The video then shifts to a series of tweets displayed on a black background, featuring updates about participants in the #BM100 event, including their names, times, and achievements. The tweets are from a user named Keith, with various engagement metrics such as likes, retweets, and comments visible. The video then moves to an indoor setting where a person in a dark robe is seated on a couch, surrounded by medals and trophies on the wall behind them, with a colorful light strip and a shelf with water bottles and a sign reading 'SWIFT' in the background. The person appears to be speaking, as indicated by their hand gestures and facial expressions. The video continues with more tweets from the same user, discussing the Barkley finishers and expressing regret over a tweet that led to a situation involving Damian Hall. The video concludes with the person in the dark robe continuing to speak, maintaining the same indoor setting with the medals, trophies, colorful light strip, and 'SWIFT' sign in the background.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with an excited male voice announcing that John Kelly has completed his third Barkley marathon finish. He follows this with disappointment about the news that Damian Hall was unable to complete loop 5, having taken a shorter route back to camp. The speaker expresses sorrow for Damian, but then assures that he will be back to try again. The audio clip is underscored by upbeat music that creates a sense of excitement.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man in a gray t-shirt and black shorts standing next to a woman in an orange long-sleeve shirt, who is seated in a black folding chair, holding a cup. They are in a wooded area with a yellow and black barrier in the background, marked with a sign that reads 'NOT BACK GATE.' The scene transitions to a man in a green jacket and blue cap standing in front of a wooden sign that reads 'Frozen Head State Park & Natural Area,' indicating the location. The video then shifts to an indoor setting where a man in a dark robe is seated on a couch, surrounded by various medals and trophies on the wall behind him, suggesting a space dedicated to achievements. The next scene shows a man in a green and blue striped shirt holding a cup, conversing with a woman in a blue shirt and beige beanie in a wooded area with a stone wall and a white tent in the background. The video returns to the indoor setting, where the man in the dark robe continues to speak, with a shelf of water bottles and a sign that reads 'SNIFT' visible in the background. The video concludes with the man in the dark robe still seated on the couch, maintaining the same indoor environment with the medals, trophies, and 'SNIFT' sign in the background.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a single male speaker announcing that Jared Campbell finished next and made it four finishes of the Barkley Marathons, an amazing effort after a DNF last year. He then identifies Greg Hamilton as the next runner to finish, congratulating him, and ends by stating that Sebastian Racon from France didn't quite finish, perhaps returning for another crack next year. The speaker has an excited tone throughout.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man in a dark robe sitting on a couch, surrounded by various medals and trophies on the wall behind him, indicating a history of achievements. The room is warmly lit, with a colorful LED strip light adding a modern touch. The scene transitions to an outdoor setting where a woman in an orange long-sleeve shirt and a backpack is seen hiking with trekking poles, navigating through a wooded area. The focus then shifts back to the man in the robe, who appears to be speaking, as suggested by his mouth movements and the changing colors of the LED light behind him. The video then shows a group of people in a forested area, with one person in an orange shirt and another in a black shirt with the text "DISTRICT TERMINATOR" visible, suggesting a group activity or event. The scene returns to the man in the robe, continuing his speech, before transitioning to an outdoor setting where a person in an orange shirt and black shorts is seen running on a paved road, using trekking poles for support. The video captures the dynamic movement of the runner, emphasizing the physical activity and the natural environment. The video concludes with the man in the robe, still speaking, with the LED light behind him displaying a gradient of colors, adding a visual element to his presentation.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with excited male narration focused on Jasmine Paris as the sole competitor left in the Barkley Marathon, with only minutes to spare. He describes their constant refreshing of Twitter, called X, and their attempts to contact friends at the campsite for information. The speaker then notes the fact that even though it's dark where he is, it is daytime in Tennessee, saying that it's just easier to imagine it in the dark. The tone remains enthusiastic as he relays that with less than two minutes to go, a tweet came from Keith Dunn.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a series of tweets from a user named Keith, discussing the completion of the 2024 Barkley Marathons, highlighting the achievements of several runners, including Jasmine Paris, Sebastian Raichon, and Greg Hamilton. The scene then transitions to a man in a dark robe sitting in a room adorned with medals and trophies, suggesting a celebratory or reflective atmosphere. The video then shifts to an outdoor setting where a group of people is gathered around a stone wall, capturing a moment of celebration or recognition. The crowd, consisting of spectators and photographers, is focused on a runner in a red shirt who is being congratulated. The environment is a wooded area with a rustic feel, indicated by the stone wall and the natural surroundings. The video captures the excitement and communal spirit of the event, with people taking photos and videos to commemorate the occasion. The scene then returns to the man in the robe, who appears to be sharing his thoughts or experiences related to the event, providing a personal connection to the narrative. The video effectively blends the digital and physical worlds, highlighting both the online community's engagement and the real-life celebration of the marathon participants.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with excited speech, announcing Jasmine Paris having touched the Yellow Gate, describing her as the "first woman to finish the Barkley Marathons ever" and emphasizing its historical significance since 1986. The speaker is male, energetic, and congratulatory, stating this moment is "overdue" and opens doors for women in ultra-running. He then notes Jasmine's finishing time, calling it cutting it fine, expressing congratulations to other finishers like Jarrad, John, and Greg, and praising Ihor who came in first, before expressing excitement for the 2025 event. The speech is clear and enthusiastic throughout.
